texts.shortText: Easily recognized by the fact that it has eight shell plates in a circle (all other intertidal species in the region have either six or four) and reaches a relatively large size compared to other similar intertidal species. Shell plates dirty white and bearing prominent, meandering vertical ridges. Very common in the mid- to low-intertidal, forming extensive and often closely-packed sheets.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to south-coast of KwaZulu-Natal.

One of most common intertidal barnacles in the region, forming extensive sheets in the mid to low intertidal, especially in areas of relatively high wave action. A passive feeder, holding its feeding appendages out into the waves and sieving out passing food particles.
Like all barnacles feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.

Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies which facilitate later mating.

Can be readily distinguished from other regional species by having 8-shell valves in the circle. Other smaller white and vertically ridged, but 6-shelled species, such as Chthamalus dentatus and Balanus glandula are also common in similar intertidal habitats.

Boland, JM (1997). The horizontal zonation of two species of intertidal barnacle in South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 18(1), 49–61.

Delafontaine, MT & Flemming, BW (1989). Physical factors in barnacle community structure: a conceptual model. Scientia Marina, 53(2), 405–410.
